title: الإِمَالَة
description: Learn about الإِمَالَة (vowel tilting/inclination) in Arabic, a phonetic feature where fatha tilts toward kasra and alif tilts toward ya, including الإمالة الكبرى and الإمالة الصغرى.

notes.title: What is الإِمَالَة?
content: الإِمَالَة (vowel tilting or inclination) is a phonetic phenomenon where the فَتْحَة tilts toward كَسْرَة, and the أَلِف tilts toward يَاء. Instead of a pure 'a' sound, it becomes closer to 'e'. This was a feature of certain Arab dialects.

For example, the word هُدًى (guidance) in standard pronunciation has a final 'a' sound, but with الإمالة it sounds closer to 'hude'. This phenomenon is preserved in certain Quranic readings (قِرَاءَات), particularly the reading of Hamzah and Al-Kisa'i.

notes.title: الإِمَالَة الكُبْرَى
content: الإِمَالَة الكُبْرَى (major tilting) is when the فَتْحَة fully tilts to approach كَسْرَة, and the أَلِف fully approaches يَاء. The 'a' sound becomes very close to 'e' or 'i'. This is also called الإِمَالَة المَحْضَة (pure tilting).
Major imala is found in the reading of Hamzah (حَمْزَة) and Al-Kisa'i (الكِسَائِي) in words like النَّار، الكَافِرِين. It was characteristic of the dialect of Najd and some eastern Arab tribes.
keyPoints: Feature of Najdi and eastern dialects

notes.title: الإِمَالَة الصُّغْرَى
content: الإِمَالَة الصُّغْرَى (minor tilting), also called التَّقْلِيل (diminution) or بَيْنَ بَيْنَ (between-between), is a partial tilt. The فَتْحَة moves slightly toward كَسْرَة, but not as much as in الكبرى.
This type is characteristic of the reading of Warsh (وَرْش) from Nafi', found in North African and West African Quranic recitation. It represents a middle ground between pure fatha and full imala.
keyPoints: Found in قِرَاءَة وَرْش عَنْ نَافِع

notes.title: Causes and Conditions of الإِمَالَة
content: Imala typically occurs in specific environments: (1) when the alif is derived from ي (ألف منقلبة عن ياء), as in هُدَى from يَهْدِي, (2) when there is a كَسْرَة near the alif, (3) when the word ends in ى مقصورة.

Imala is blocked (مَوَانِع الإمالة) by certain letters called حُرُوف الاسْتِعْلَاء (emphatic letters: ص، ض، ط، ظ، خ، غ، ق) because their heavy articulation prevents the light sound of imala. Understanding these causes and blockers is essential for proper tajweed.
keyPoints: Causes: ألف from ياء, nearby كسرة, ى مقصورة
ص، ض، ط، ظ، خ، غ، ق block imala

examples.english: he threw (from yarmee) -> can have imala
he raided (has emphatic غ) -> no imala
